newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Palm oil seen hitting temperate oil market share.
newsitem.headline: Palm oil seen hitting temperate oil market share.

text.p: Genetic-engineering can help palm oil erode the market share of soybean and olive oils, an expert said on Wednesday.

"Scientists in the United States have modified canola oil to make it look more like coconut oil for industrial use," Nam-Hai Chua, chairman of the scientific advisory board at the National University of Singapore, told Reuters.
"They are encroaching on our market share and we have to mount a response," he said in an interview on the fringes of an international food conference in Jakarta.

Chua, who is also head of the laboratory of plant molecular biology at Rockefeller University in New York, said there was a general perception that the high content of saturated fatty acids found in palm oil was not good for health.
"Six-seven years ago, there was a negative campaign by the soybean growers of the United States against Malaysian palm oil," he said. "They were using it as a competitive measure."
He said bio-technology could be used to reduce the acid content in palm oil and raise its mono-unsaturated fatty acid level to make its properties similar to olive oil.
"Then the health issue will no longer be valid and they (soybean growers) will have to think of other things, while you expand greatly the product use of palm oil," he said.
Indonesia is the world's top producer of palm oil after neighbouring Malaysia. Palm oil is used to make cooking oil, soaps and detergents, cosmetics and fabric softeners.
Chua said bio-technology can help countries such as Indonesia and Malaysia harvest different sorts of products with higher value and expand their market share.

"Palm oil can compete with temperate oils, and can begin to erode the market share of olive oil and soybean oil," he said, adding that bio-technology can no longer be ignored when considering business issues.
"It can reconfigure the supply chain," he added.
He said breakthroughs in genetic-engineering of plants were just the tip of the iceberg, adding that there would be waves of second and third generation products.
Bacteria-resistant rice plants, vegetables with longer shelf-lives and flowers that bloom longer are some of the many advances chalked up through genetic-modification of plants.
